overview.short: Psychrobacter species are Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, non-fermenting short rods or coccobacilli, adapted to cold environments.
overview.clinical_context: Occasionally isolated from human clinical specimens including blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and wounds, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

field_notes.Shape: Often described as coccobacilli; mapped to Short Rods in this schema.
field_notes.Growth Temperature: Psychrotolerant; many species grow at refrigeration temperatures.
field_notes.Oxidase: Consistently positive, supporting separation from many Enterobacterales.

key_differentiators.notes: Ability to grow at low temperatures is characteristic of Psychrobacter.
Non-motility helps exclude many other oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods.

common_confusions.reason: Both are Gram-negative, oxidase-variable short rods; Psychrobacter is oxidase-positive and psychrotolerant.
Similar oxidase-positive, non-motile profile; growth temperature and MALDI-TOF aid differentiation.

when_to_question_identification: Strong carbohydrate fermentation is inconsistent with the genus.
Motility suggests a different non-fermenting genus.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports psychrotolerant phenotype characteristic of Psychrobacter.
Useful biochemical panel for non-fermenting Gram-negative rods.
Most reliable method for genus and species-level identification.
